section.name: How to install AndroMDA
section.p:
Download, unzip, CLASSPATH!
(or was it "Ready ... steady ... go!" ?)
The installation of AndroMDA itself is quite easy (the real challenge will come later!).

Download the distribution file andromda-bin-*.zip from the
AndroMDA file list
on SourceForge's web site and unzip it into a directory of your choice. You will notice that it has a release number at the end of the filename. After unzipping, you will notice the following directory structure inside:

tr.td: Core of the generator, along with documentation and source files.
Home of the pluggable cartridges that generate different kinds of output files: EJBs, Hibernate objects, Struts applications, plain Java files.
Complete documentation as you read here.

Several sample applications of AndroMDA, including:
a complete J2EE sample application (a car rental system), generated with AndroMDA from a UML model that is also included
a template for an empty project using EJB technology
a template for an empty project using Hibernate technology
a project that shows how to generate something using all the model information in one template.
The directory also contains wizard.xml, a small script that can create empty projects for you to start with (see "Getting started").

section.p: Unzip the files you need into a directory of your choice. Be prepared to insert jar files from these directories onto the classpath of your build.properties script (see instructions later in this text). AndroMDA will auto-detect a cartridge if its main jar file (e.g. andromda-hibernate.jar) is on the classpath when AndroMDA is run.

p.b: Other software that you will need

section.p:
AndroMDA is based upon some other software components that you will need to download from the Internet and include in the CLASSPATH of your build script. These components are:
Ant - the famous build tool, made by the Apache Jakarta project. You can download it from
the Apache Ant website
. Unpack ant into a directory of your choice and set the environment variable ANT_HOME to the name of that directory before you run your personal Ant build script.
JBoss - a very popular open source application server. You can download it from
the JBoss website
. Unpack it into a directory and set the property jboss.home in your build.properties before you run your ant build scripts.

Recompiling AndroMDA from the source is quite easy. Unpack andromda-src-*.zip into a directory of your choice. Copy build.properties.sample to build.properties and edit it. Insert the directory where you installed JBoss as a value for the property jboss.home. That's it! Run ant and watch the contents of the "dist" subdirectory!

The same rules apply if you want to compile the CVS version. Checkout the andromda-all module from
AndroMDA CVS
instead of unzipping the released sources, then proceed as before.

news.name: Velocity
news.p: Velocity is a product written by the famous Apache Jakarta project. It can be used to generate Java, web pages, SQL, PostScript and other output from templates. It can be used either as a standalone utility for generating source code and reports, or as an integrated component of other systems.

news.name: JUnit
news.p: JUnit is a regression testing framework written by Erich Gamma and Kent Beck. It is used by the developer who implements unit tests in Java. JUnit is Open Source Software, released under the IBM's Common Public License Version 1.0 and hosted on SourceForge.

news.name: XDoclet
news.p: XDoclet is a code generation engine. It enables Attribute-Oriented Programming for java. In short, this means that you can add more significance to your code by adding meta data (attributes) to your java sources. This is done in special JavaDoc tags.
